summary: Around the world, the COVID-19 pandemic has had a dramatic impact on the flow of goods from producers to consumers. For many businesses, weak links in supply chains have caused disruption and damage. Containment measures and staff shortages have forced processing plants to scale back or shut down, for example, leaving suppliers scrambling to adjust their output.

All across the world, companies, workers and customers are eager to return to normal, but they know it can’t be business as usual. Emerging from a crisis like COVID-19 means making careful choices about how, and with whom, you do business. Now more than ever, people are embracing companies they know and trust—and avoiding those that they don’t.

This year, our future arrived faster than we expected. We've all had to find unique ways of connecting, learning, and working in this new all-digital world. “The Pivot Point” follows leading brands who have grown through the pandemic with groundbreaking strategies and digital tools that have allowed them to stay connected to their customers, unite their business processes, and protect their employees.

headline: Many Americans are weary of polling data, but here's what can be trusted from the latest numbers

headline: How the 2020 election war on bots and trolls differs from 2016
summary: The 2016 election exposed how social media could be used by a foreign adversary to sow dissent and distrust within American borders. In 2020, the fight against those threats rages on, and the number of players has expanded, abroad and domestically. At the center of the fight against misinformation and polarization on social media are bots and trolls. Understanding how they operate could be the key to fighting their influence.
